The development, implementation, and analysis of forest policy. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third- or fourth-year standing.
Introduction to the quantitative tools necessary in forest management. Available only through Distance Education.

course_name: Mathematical Modelling in Forest Resource Analysis
prerequisites: /* Unparsed: fourth-year standing in the bsf degree. */
description: Modelling techniques used in strategic and tactical forest resources analyses. [2-0-3] Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in the BSF degree.
Forest management designs to identify and integrate economic, social, and environmental objectives across a forested landscape both strategically and tactically. [4-2-2] Prerequisite: FRST 422.

Analyze and interpret existing management plans, prescribe solutions for achieving specific forest management goals at multiple scales, use basic tools to evaluate the financial implications of such solutions, and create a forest management plan for a virtual forest. Offered entirely online. Students in any of the Forestry programs requiring FRST 423 (6 cr) in order to graduate will not be granted the 3 cr of FRST 425 toward degree completion.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="FRST 231"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="NRES 231"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="BIOL 300"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="STAT 200"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="FRST 399"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="WITH 4")])

The genomic basis of adaptation to environments. Topics progress through community structure, life history patterns, stress responses, and variation and adaptation. [3-0-0]

Techniques of growth and yield projection and discussion of modelling approaches. Exploration of stand dynamics, quantitative implications of management treatments and environmental limitations to tree and stand growth. [2-2-0] Prerequisite: FRST339

The socio-economic, biological and technological aspects of forestry within the international frame, in both the developed and developing world. Regional studies and the role of national and international agencies. [2-2-0]

Basic biological concepts related to interpretation of remote sensing data for land management, including the use of films and filters, and interpretation of air photographs, and other imagery. [2-2-0]

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="FRST 201"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="NRES 201"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="APBI 260")])

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 152"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 221"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 223")])
description: Linear programming problems, dual problems, the simplex algorithm, solution of primal and dual problems, sensitivity analysis. Additional topics chosen from: Karmarkar's algorithm, non-linear programming, game theory, applications. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 220"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 223"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 226"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="CPSC 121")])
description: Introduction to ideas and methods of discrete mathematics and their application. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 220, MATH 223, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 152"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 221"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 220"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 226"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="CPSC 121"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 223")])
description: Error-correcting codes via abstract and linear algebra. Emphasis on proofs and computation. Finite fields, Hamming distance and error-correction, upper and lower bounds on the size of a code, linear codes, groups and cosets, encoding and decoding schemes. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of MATH 152, MATH 221 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121; or (b) MATH 223.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 152"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 221"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 220"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 226"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="CPSC 121"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 223")])
description: Introduction to mathematical game theory and its applications. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) one of MATH 152, MATH 221 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121; or (b) MATH 223.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="OF 68"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 215"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 255"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 256"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 258")])
description: Phase plane methods, bifurcation and stability theory, limit-cycle behavior and chaos for nonlinear differential equations with applications to the sciences. Assignments involve the use of computers. [3-1-0] Prerequisite: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.

Fourier series; auto- and cross-correlation; power spectra; discrete Fourier transform; boundary-value problems; numerical methods; partial differential equations; heat, wave, Laplace, Poisson, and wave equations. Applications to mechanical engineering and practical computing applications emphasized. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 358 or MATH 358. [3-2*-0] Prerequisite: All of MECH 224, MECH 225. Equivalency: MECH358

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 200"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 217"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 226"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 253"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 254"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 210"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="CPSC 203"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="CPSC 210"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 215"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 255"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 256"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 258")])
description: Construction and evaluation of deterministic, stochastic, and data-driven models. Software-assisted simulations and numerical solutions involving ordinary differential equations, stochastic processes, and basic machine learning algorithms. Examples from science, engineering, and economics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 254 and one of MATH 210, CPSC 203, CPSC 210 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="BIOL 301"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 215"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 255"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 256"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 258")])
description: Mathematical modelling of basic biological processes in ecology, physiology, neuroscience and genetics. Dynamic behavior of difference equations, differential equations, and partial differential equations, explained with reference to concrete biological examples. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of BIOL 301, MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.

Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program. Prerequisite: MATH 398. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 300"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 305"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 256"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 257"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 316"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 358"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MECH 358"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="PHYS 312")])
description: Separation of variables, first order equations, Sturm-Liouville theory, integral transform methods. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 300, MATH 305 and one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="OF 80"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 256"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 257"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 316"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 358"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MECH 358"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="PHYS 312"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 400")])
description: Green's functions for partial differential equations. Calculus of variations. Eigenfunction expansions. Rayleigh-Ritz and finite element methods. See Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312 or (b) MATH 400.

Classical variational problems; necessary conditions of Euler, Weierstrass, Legendre, and Jacobi; Erdmann corner conditions, transversality, convex Lagrangians, fields of extremals, sufficient conditions for optimality, numerical methods; applications to classical mechanics, engineering and economics. Recommended pre-requisites: a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 301, MATH 320, or, a score of 80% or higher in MATH 319. [3-0-0]

course_name: Stabilization and Optimal Control of Dynamical Systems
description: Dynamical systems; stability by Liapunov's direct method; controllability and eigenvalue assignment for autonomous linear systems; linear-quadratic regulator, time optimal control, Pontryagin maximum principle, dynamic programming; applications in engineering, economics and resource management. Recommended pre-requisites: MATH 402, and one of (a) a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 301, MATH 320, or (b) a score of 80% or higher in MATH 319. [3-0-0]

Harmonic analysis on Euclidean spaces, with applications to number theory, partial differential equations and geometric measure theory. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 300 and a score of 68% or higher in MATH 321. Corequisite: MATH 420.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 256"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 257"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 316"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 358"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MECH 358"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="PHYS 312")])
description: Interpolation, numerical integration, numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations. Practical computational methods emphasized and basic theory developed through simple models. See Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312.

course_name: Variational and Approximate Methods in Applied Mathematics
prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 307"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="CPSC 302"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="OF 80"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 256"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 257"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 316"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 358"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MECH 358"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="PHYS 312"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 400")])
description: Variational and Green's function methods for ordinary and partial differential equations, introduction to finite difference, finite element and boundary element methods. See Faculty of Science Credit exclusion list: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult… [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 307, CPSC 302 and either (a) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316, MATH 358, MECH 358, PHYS 312 or (b) MATH 400.

prerequisites: /* Unparsed: a score of 68% or higher in math 322 and either (a) a score of 68% or higher in math 320 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in math 319. */
description: Topics include decompositions of linear operators, multilinear algebra, bilinear forms, metric spaces. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 322 and either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 320 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in MATH 319.

Students will prepare material illustrating ideas and applications of mathematics and present it to audiences outside the University. Intended for third or fourth year Mathematics students and Math/Science Education students. [2-0-0; 1-0-0] or [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 24 credits in MATH.

Probability spaces, random variables, distributions, expectation, conditional probabilities, convergence of random variables, generating and characteristic functions, weak and strong laws of large numbers, central limit theorem. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 321. Prerequisite grade requirement: 68% in MATH321.
Random walks, Markov chains, branching processes, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains, martingales, Brownian motion. [3-0-0].Prerequisite: MATH 418.

Sigma-algebras, Lebesgue measure, Borel measures, measurable functions, integration, convergence theorems, Lp spaces, Holder and Minkowski inequalities, Lebesgue and/or Radon-Nikodym differentiation. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 321. Prerequisite grade requirement: 68% in MATH321.

Banach spaces, linear operators, bounded and compact operators, strong, weak, and weak* topology. Hahn-Banach, open mapping, and closed graph theorems. Hilbert spaces, symmetric and self-adjoint operators, spectral theory for bounded operators. [3-0-0]. Prerequisite: MATH 420.
Field extensions, the Galois correspondence, finite fields, insolvability in radicals, ruler and compass constructions, additional topics chosen by instructor. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 323.
Commutative algebra; homological algebra or representation theory of finite groups. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 323 and a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 412, MATH 422.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="OF 68"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 223"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="OF 80"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 152"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 221"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="OF 68"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 227"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="OF 80"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 217"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 254"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 264"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 317")])
description: The differential geometry of curves and surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space. Mean curvature and Gaussian curvature. Geodesics. Gauss's Theorema Egregium. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 223 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 152, MATH 221; and either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 227 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 217, MATH 254, MATH 264, MATH 317.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 221"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 223"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 217"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 227"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 254"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 264"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 317"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 319"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 320")])
description: Smooth manifolds, smooth maps, immersions and submersions, vector fields, vector bundles, tangent and cotangent bundles, tensors and differential forms, orientation of manifolds, integration of forms, and selected topics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 254, MATH 264, MATH 317 and one of MATH 319, MATH 320.

General topology, combinatorial topology, fundamental group and covering spaces, topics chosen by the instructor. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: All of MATH 321, MATH 322. Prerequisite grade requirement: 68% in MATH322,MATH321.
Homology theory, homotopy theory, manifolds, and other topics chosen by the instructor. [3-0-0]. Prerequisite: MATH 426.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 215"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 255"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 256"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 258"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="PHYS 216"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="PHYS 306"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="ENPH 270")])
description: Newton's equation, conservation laws, the Euler-Lagrange equation; Hamilton's principle of least action, Hamilton's equations, Lagrangian mechanics on manifolds. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258 and one of PHYS 216, PHYS 306, ENPH 270. Corequisite: MATH 320 (waived for students with a score of 80% or higher in MATH 319).

corequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 320"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="OF 80"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 319"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 322")])
description: Divisibility, congruences, Diophantine equations, arithmetic functions, quadratic reciprocity, advanced topics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facult…. [3-0-0] Corequisite: One of MATH 320 (waived for students with a score of 80% or higher in MATH 319), MATH 322.

The residue theorem, the argument principle, conformal mapping, the maximum modulus principle, harmonic functions, representation of functions by integrals, series, and products. Other topics at the discretion of the instructor. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 300 and either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 320 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in MATH 319 and permission of the Department Head in Mathematics.

Formulation of real-world optimization problems using techniques such as linear programming, network flows, integer programming, dynamic programming. Solution by appropriate software. [3-0-0]. Prerequisite: MATH 340.

description: Graph theory, emphasizing trees, tree growing algorithms, and proof techniques. Other topics chosen from shortest paths, maximum flows, minimum cost flows, matchings, and graph colouring. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 3rd year standing and one of MATH 220, MATH 223, MATH 226 or CPSC 221.

Proofs emphasized. Intended for Honours students. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 220, MATH 223, MATH 226, CPSC 121. And 6 credits of MATH numbered 300 or above.

prerequisites: Prerequisite(type="one_of", children=[Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 220"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="MATH 226"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="AND 6"), Prerequisite(type="course", details="NUMBERED 300")])
description: Current research topics in pure and applied mathematics are explored at the undergraduate level. Technical communication and research skills are developed. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 220, MATH 226. and 6 credits of MATH courses numbered 300 or higher.

course_name: Topics in the History of Mathematics I
description: Historical development of concepts and techniques in areas chosen from Geometry, Number Theory, Algebra, Calculus, Probability, Analysis. The focus is on historically significant writings of important contributors and on famous problems of Mathematics. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: 21 credits of MATH.

description: Introduction to the methods of mathematical research through an exploration of a mathematical topic under the supervision of a faculty member. Written report required. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Third- or fourth-year standing and permission of the Department Head.

Asymptotic expansions. Asymptotic evaluation of integrals; WKBJ methods. Regular and singular expansions. Boundary layer theory; matched asymptotic expansions. Multiple scale techniques. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: MATH 400.

description: Computational methods for mathematical modelling. Numerical methods for partial differential equations, stochastic processes, and data-driven models. Includes student-directed projects on current research and applications. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Either (a) MATH 360 or (b) one of MATH 210, CPSC 203, CPSC 210 and one of MATH 345, MATH 361.

Development and analysis of mathematical models for complex systems in ecology, evolution, cell biology, neurophysiology, and other biological and medical disciplines. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of MATH 361, MATH 345.

Optimal control of systems governed by ordinary differential equations. The control problem will be carefully stated, and existence results and necessary conditions will be established. Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman theory will be introduced. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Ideas, methods and applications of bifurcation theory and dynamical systems: differential and difference equations, local bifurcations, perturbation methods, chaos. Recommended pre-requisites: one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256 and one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Topics from: hyperbolic invariant sets and symbolic dynamics, global bifurcations, local bifurcations for partial differential equations, multiple bifurcations, bifurcations and symmetry, applications. Prerequisite: MATH 552. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Dimensional analysis, modelling, and invariance. Lie groups of transformations, infinitesimal transformations. Applications to ordinary and partial differential equations. No knowledge of group theory will be assumed. Recommended pre-requisite: elementary courses in differential equations and linear algebra. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Classical and recent results in linear and nonlinear waves. Geometrical acoustics and kinematic waves; large amplitude waves in weakly stratified media; small amplitude waves in strongly stratified media. Dispersive waves; group velocity; applications. Recommended pre-requisites: MATH 400 and some knowledge of either fluid mechanics or elasticity. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.
Mathematical methods in modelling biological processes, at levels from cell biochemistry to community ecology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

course_name: Mathematics of Infectious Diseases and Immunology
description: Mathematical models for disease spread in populations. Within-host infectious disease dynamics. Models of the immune system and immune cells. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Formulation and analysis of models of excitable media. FitzHugh-Nagumo model, ionic models of membrane excitability (e.g., Hodgkin-Huxley), calcium excitability, bursting phenomena. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Concepts and techniques for modelling cellular and subcellular dynamics in biological systems. Topics may include complex biochemical systems, biopolymers in cell motility and division, continuum mechanics, and membrane dynamics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Mathematical models of evolution and evolutionary game theory. Stochastic dynamics in finite populations, dynamics in spatially structured populations, and adaptive dynamics. Applications include the origin of species and the problem of cooperation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Ethics, jurisprudence, practice management, intra- and interprofessional relationships. [2-0-0]
